channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline
channel.description: RSS feed for the Mastodon Home timeline

item.title: @AllenNeuroLab
item.description: Dear Mastodon #neuroscience folks. I’ve been trying to switch my SciSocial time from Twitter/X. However, I have not found there to be much in the way of scientific conversations or community on this platform (some from people I already knew on Twitter/X mostly). Posts don’t seem to drive conversations, and finding posts takes a lot of effort here but not there. What am I missing? Honest question. Thanks for any replies! (btw, not wanting platform ethical comparisons for this post)

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description: Hello again Mastodon/fediverse, any good topics about the brain to discuss today?? 😅

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: What's the German word for that feeling of being on a long flight and you've watched a movie and eaten something and stretched your legs and you're all "yep, 'bout ready to land..." ...but you check and you've got 5 more hours to go?

item.title: Cori Bargmann
item.description: @AllenNeuroLab I’m optimistic about the potential of groups like @neuroscience and @neurobuzz. But I’m still experiencing the same issue as you are, partly because this instance makes it difficult to find or follow people on other instances. I’ll keep trying. At least I get the @biorxivpreprint feed.

item.title: Bruce Hamilton
item.description:
Leo Szilard’s short story The Mark Gable Foundation is a classic. The satire of how-to-retard-science will be familiar to anyone whose work relies on research grants. If you can find a copy of his collection Voice of the Dolphins, get it. The typed manuscript is among his papers available online from #UCSD libraries: https://library.ucsd.edu/dc/object/bb33804055Came up in conversation the other day, so posting it here for anyone who might be interested.
#science #grants #szilard #sandiego #sciencefiction

item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description:
Does your university consider legacy status (e.g., children of alumni) in admissions? If so, why? Legacy admissions give advantages to students that already have advantages. What purpose does the practice serve, and is it ethically worth it?
http://labrigger.com/blog/2023/07/30/end-legacy-considerations-in-college-admissions/

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Did evolution create a tradeoff between walking upright and childbirth? For my new column I wrote about a new debate about an old ideas. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/30/science/childbirth-evolution-obstetrical-dilemma.html

item.title: Mackenzie Mathis 🦄
item.description: And now accepted at #ICCV2023

item.title: Kai Sandbrink
item.description: Now a bit late to Mastodon! In https://elifesciences.org/articles/81499, we show how task-driven modelling can be used to investigate the computational role of the proprioceptive system by training neural nets and comparing emergent representations side-by-side for different hypothesesThanks to @TrackingActions and @TrackingPlumes for the great supervision and @pranavm (equal contribution) and other coauthors for the great collaboration!

item.title: Total Internal Reflection
item.description: New posting! This one is a #HowTo guide on how NOT to start a research group in #academia - in other words, all the things that I wish I'd done differently or that I wish I'd been more aware of when I started back in 2015. I hope that helps anyone else out there taking their first steps in this direction! (And any comments/additions very welcome). 👇 https://totalinternalreflectionblog.com/2023/07/30/shutting-up-shop-a-short-guide-on-how-not-to-start-a-research-group/

item.title: Jonathan Z Simon
item.description:
#introduction #neuroscience
Hi, I’m Jonathan Simon, new to fediscience.org, so I'm posting a new introduction. I’m an auditory neuroscientist, dad, husband, and nerd.Research-wise, I’m really interested in how the brain processes complex sounds, like attended speech in a noisy background (“the cocktail party problem”). Typically in this case, our perception is dramatically dissociated from the physical acoustics (and not at all a reliable indicator of the sounds entering our ears).
1/3

item.title: Gaspar Jekely
item.description: Here is my #introduction. I am a biologist interested in #neuroscience and the #evolution of cells and nervous systems. My research group studies #ciliated marine larvae from a whole-organism perspective, combining behaviour, #connectomics, #imaging, #CRISPR, #modelling and other approaches. We love marine #larvae, their #neurons, #cilia, and #neuropeptides.

item.title: Chuck Darwin
item.description: The Origin of Student Debt: Regan advisor warned that Free College would create a Dangerous Educated ProletariatIt’s important to understand how Americans came to #owe the current cumulative total of *more than $1.6 trillion* for higher education.In 1970, Ronald Reagan was running for reelection as governor of California. He had first won in 1966 with confrontational rhetoric toward the University of California public college system and executed confrontational policies when in office. In May 1970, Reagan shut down all 28 UC and Cal State campuses in the midst of student protests against the Vietnam War and the U.S. bombing of Cambodia. On October 29, less than a week before the election, his education adviser #Roger A. #Freeman spoke at a press conference to defend him.Freeman’s remarks were reported the next day in the San Francisco Chronicle under the headline “Professor Sees Peril in Education.” According to the Chronicle article, Freeman said, “We are in #danger of producing an #educated #proletariat. … That’s dynamite! We have to be #selective on who we #allow [to go to college].”“If not,” Freeman continued, “we will have a large number of highly trained and unemployed people.” Freeman also said — taking a highly idiosyncratic perspective on the cause of fascism —“that’s what happened in Germany. I saw it happen.”https://theintercept.com/2022/08/25/student-loans-debt-reagan/

item.title: DailyMegafauna
item.description: Today’s #megafauna is the Portuguese man o’ war. Although it is often mistaken for a #jellyfish, the man-o-war is actually a #siphonophore, composed of multiple, genetically distinct, individual polyps. One of these polyps is the gas-filled float, which projects above the surface of the water and helps the man o' war float through the #oceans. This purple-blue float apparently resembles the wind-filled #sail of the 18th century warship from which the man o' war gets its name. When the man o' war encounters a threat on the ocean’s surface, this float can temporarily deflate to escape. Beneath the surface, three more polyps are attached to the float. One of these polyps digests food for the entire colony, another handles the man o' war’s sexual reproduction, and the third forms its #tentacles. These tentacles are, on average, 30 feet long, but can reach lengths up to 165 feet. They aid the man o' war in hunting by delivering a poison that paralyzes or kills smaller fish and sea creatures. The tentacles’ muscles then transport the unmoving prey upwards to the digestive polyp. For humans, the tentacles’ sting is incredibly painful–and it can be delivered even after the man o' war dies and washes ashore. Human deaths from man o' war stings are very rare, and usually involve allergic reactions or cardiac events. Although the stinging tentacles protect the man-o-war from many threats, it does have some natural predators. Sunfish and loggerhead turtles, which also eat jellyfish, are common predators. Several species use the man o' wars tentacles for their own defenses: the blanket octopus attaches man o' war tentacles to their own, and blue sea dragons store the man o' wars' poison-delivering nematocysts for later use. With no propulsive anatomy, man o' wars drift through the ocean with no control over their own location. Changes in wind and current patterns can drastically alter the distribution of this species from year to year. They are often found floating together in groups which can number in the thousands. Man o' wars are distributed throughout the warmer areas of Earth’s oceans–and rising temperatures are allowing them to survive in a larger range, with specimens washing ashore as far north as #Canada and #Scotland.

item.title: Climatematch
item.description:
We had some amazing live discussions with highly skilled individuals in the field of climate science during our Career Panels. You can access the recordings for free on our YouTube playlist.https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLnpWOQFK76gpALjLfwWroP0ix5Mk1N98x
Dr. Shipra Jain, Former Executive Committee member, Young Earth System Scientists Community
Mpho Sadiki, Earth Observation Data Scientist, Digital Earth Africa
Dr. Yaítza Luna-Cruz, Program Executive, Chief Science Data Office, NASA Science Mission Directory (NASA TOPS)
Steven Ramage, CEO of Réseau & Senior Business Advisor for United Nations
Dr. Sheila Saia, Associate Director for North Carolina State Climate Office
Dr. Faten Attig-Bahar, University of Carthage, Future Earth Water/Energy/Food Nexus
